content:
Neither do I know what's your "best email address" nor is there a "Mozilla account". Thunderbird is an application run on your device, so it does not provide email addresses, nor the service to transmit emails. But Thunderbird can be used with your existing email address and service provider to send, receive, sort and search your email messages.

What are you trying to achieve in the first place?
creator: christ1

content:
I've got hundreds of contacts in the Zoho program's "Address Book" and I can't find a similar thing in gmail

I'm not exatcly sure what you're looking for. Google has Google Contacts, which is web based, so you can manage your contacts via a web browser. https://contacts.google.com/

On top of that you could create an address book in Thunderbird linked to your Google Contacts.

after many hours of searching online to try to figure out how to export the address book to gmail and finally learning it can't be done, I'm hoping to learn how to add the gmail program to Thunderbird.

I have no idea about Zoho, so I can't help with exporting your contacts from there. Alternatively you could create the Google Contacts address book in Thunderbird and manually enter your contacts in Thunderbird. They will then be synced automatically with your Google Contacts. Entering contacts manually isn't a fun job, and I don't know how many cintacts you have. So I'm not sure if this would be an option at all.

I'm going to turn 77 in a few months. Maybe I should give up all this tech stuff.

You certainly should not give up.
creator: christ1

content: Pressing the junk indicator does not create a black list; it only marks this one message as junk. To train the filter takes time, periodically marking both non junk and junk. This URL may be useful: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages

content:
will it delete any files/folders etc., or alter/destroy Betterbird profile?

No, it won't. And typically you wouldn't need to start with a new profile for Betterbird. You can just continue using an existing Thunderbird profile. When uninstalling Thunderbird just make sure not to select the option to delete the profile.

Having said that, it's always a good idea to create backup of the entire profile on a regular basis. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile
creator: christ1

content:

I have deleted the Thunderbird one and everything is still there and works fine. So many thanks for you quick and informative response, much appreciated! Cheers Chris.

content:
I have forgotten my cogeco, email PW accessed through the Thunderbird account.

There is no such thing as a "Thunderbird account". Thunderbird is an application running on your device, so it does not provide email addresses, nor the service to transmit emails. But Thunderbird can be used with your existing email address and service provider to send, receive, sort and search your email messages.

Therefore you'll have to check with your email provider (Cogeco) about password reset options.
creator: christ1

content: Click settings>general and untick the start page option. That page isn't really an ad, but a reminder that Thunderbird is provided free, and continues to be available only with the kind donations of users. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: Well, you do have a point of contact: here. I regret you encountered this loss, although this is not an error in Thunderbird but a setting that the user can change. Your donation is appreciated, and it is with such donations that the developers continue to review and improve the features. I concur on your concern about upgrades. You can change the updates from automatic or only with your approval at settings>general. I also encourage all users to do backups prior to authorizing updates in case of errors. Thank you for writing.
creator: davidsk

content: Sorry for the post, I figured it out from a reply from sfhowes on another thread. Unfortunately I cannot find it now to include it here. Basically what I did was, after finally finding where Linux put the .thunderbird folder ( Help - Troubleshooting information - about:profiles) I replaced the contents with the Thunderbird folder from Windows, then put the "profiles" folder contents directly into .thunderbird folder, then deleted the "profiles" folder. Then deleted the Profiles path from the two .ini folder contents. Then, after opening TB, had to choose the right profile to make it the default. Whew......
creator: sean29
